We hope that our findings will contribute to developing more efficient methods of controlling the response of such systems when exposed to various sources of noise.Overall, our work provides insight into the role of noise in reaction-diffusion systems and highlights the potential for SR to emerge in such systems. We believe that our findings have significant implications for the design and optimization of reaction-diffusion systems in various fields, including chemical engineering and biology.

We present our analysis of the radio through X-ray Spectral Energy Distributions (SEDs) of 38 Broad Absorption Line (BAL) quasars. The motivation for this study was to investigate the nature of the BAL outflows and their relationship with the accretion processes in quasars. BAL quasars are a rare type of quasar characterized by the presence of broad absorption lines in their spectra, originating from high-velocity outflows of ionized gas from the central engine. We obtained radio, optical, ultraviolet, and X-ray data from various surveys and performed spectral fitting using a self-consistent model to generate the SEDs. Our results indicate that all BAL quasars in our sample show a lack of significant radio emission compared to other types of quasars. The majority of BAL quasars are also harder in the X-ray band, which is consistent with a primary X-ray emission mechanism originating from a hot corona. We also found that the BAL outflows seem to have weaker kinetic power than those in non-BAL quasars. Our key idea is that these results support the idea that BAL outflows are triggered by the accretion process, rather than by feedback mechanisms. Our methodology is based on a multi-wavelength approach that allowed us to disentangle the various physical components contributing to the SEDs.

In this work, we investigate the possibility of obtaining a Massive CP^1 theory starting from a microscopic model for doped antiferromagnets. Our main goal is to find a Lagrangian that describes the low-energy behavior of spin excitations in a doped antiferromagnet. The starting point is a Z_2 lattice gauge theory with a spinon Fermi surface, which is believed to describe the low-energy behavior of the CuO_2 planes in cuprate superconductors. We show that by integrating out the gauge fields, one obtains an effective action for the spinons that has the form of a Massive CP^1 theory. Our approach is based on the large-N limit of the spinon theory, where N is the number of spin components. We argue that the resulting effective action is valid for small doping, where the Fermi surface is still well-defined. We then derive the equations of motion for the Massive CP^1 theory and study their properties. We find that the theory supports topological solitons, which can be interpreted as vortices in the spin texture. Our results provide a new perspective on the physics of doped antiferromagnets and may shed light on the origins of high-temperature superconductivity in cuprates.

In this paper, we investigate the continuum limit of polymer quantum mechanics. The aim of our work is to better understand the quantum behavior of polymers and its relationship to the classical theory. Our research attempts to clarify the nature of the continuum limit and determine the correctness of the approximations made. Specifically, we study the connectivity of the polymer strands. We find that a continuous path can be defined in the polymer configuration space, which is essential for the polymer to display continuum behavior. We show that the approximation of continuous randomness in the spatial variable can certainly be used when the polymer is stretched out over a significant distance. For a coil-like polymer, our results demonstrate that its behavior is non-classical.Our methodology involves a careful combination of intuition, formalism, and numerical simulations. We evaluate a path integral representation of polymer quantum mechanics in the continuum limit, and use numerical simulations to support our results. The ideas proposed in this work are relevant to the understanding of the thermodynamic properties of polymers, as well as to quantum computing and information. The findings of this work present a theoretical framework for the investigation of other polymer properties that are still poorly understood.

We present a study on the bulk viscosity of cold quark matter in the color-flavor locked phase (CFL) in this paper. Our main motivation for investigating the bulk viscosity of CFL matter is to understand the properties of quark star matter. We also aim to explore the possibility of using gravitational wave observations to infer the existence of quark stars. Despite the fact that CFL matter is not yet established to be present in the universe, its existence is backed up by theoretical work. Therefore, studying its properties is vital in ascertaining the properties of quark star matter.We discovered that the bulk viscosity of the CFL phase, unlike what is observed in normal fluids, is smaller than shear viscosity. This observation has significant implications for the behavior and dynamics of quark stars. Essentially, the damping time of processes like r-modes and ripples in gravitational waves will be much longer than previously considered. Our research aims to provide insight into the behavior of hot, dense quark matter and is a step towards understanding the characteristics of strange stars.Our study is the first to investigate the bulk viscosity of cold CFL matter. The insights provided by our work should be considered in future models of quark star stability and evolution.

In this work, we match the WMAP 3-yrs results with the Cosmological Slingshot Primordial Spectrum. Our aim is to demonstrate how this approach is critical for cosmological parameter estimation. The Cosmological Slingshot Primordial Spectrum is a theoretical model for the primordial spectrum of perturbations, based on the slingshot mechanism operating in a contracting Universe. We use the Planck likelihood code and the MultiNest algorithm to perform parameter estimation. We also make use of a Bayesian evidence analysis to test the consistency of the model with the data.Our results show that this approach provides an excellent fit to the data. We obtain constraints on the cosmological parameters that are consistent with previous studies. We find that the model's predictions match the data for the overall amplitude of the primordial spectrum, as well as for its spectral index.The problem our work attempts to solve is the precise measurement of cosmological parameters using observations of the cosmic microwave background radiation. The motivation for this research is to improve our understanding of the Universe's origins and evolution. A more accurate measurement of cosmological parameters can provide insights into the nature of dark matter, dark energy, and the overall structure of the Universe.

In this work, we aim to reconcile the observations of two branches of neutron stars: the first, a high-mass pulsar with a mass of around 2 M_sun, and the second, a neutron star formed by the explosion of the supernova SN1987A, which has a lower mass. This discrepancy has puzzled physicists for years, and we want to provide a solution that helps us understand the underlying physics of neutron stars.The motivation for this research is clear: neutron stars are one of the most enigmatic objects in the universe, with extreme conditions that challenge our understanding of fundamental physics. Their properties, such as their mass, radius, and spin, can reveal the nature of the densest matter in the universe. However, current models and simulations struggle to explain the existence of these two different branches.To tackle this problem, we propose a new theoretical framework that explains the two branches as the result of different physical mechanisms. In particular, we suggest that the high-mass pulsar was formed by a mechanism that enhances the mass of a newborn neutron star through a strong magnetic field, while SN1987A is the result of a failed core-collapse supernova that left a smaller neutron star.Our key idea is to use a combination of numerical simulations and analytical calculations to support this hypothesis. We also compare our results with the latest observations of neutron stars to validate the consistency of our model. Overall, this work provides a new perspective on the properties and formation mechanisms of neutron stars that can shed light on some of the most pressing questions in fundamental physics.

In this work, we study the high-energy emission properties of jets and blazars in the context of the Extragalactic Background Light (EBL) using data from the upcoming Gamma-ray Large Area Space Telescope (GLAST) and Energetic X-ray Imaging Survey Telescope (EXIST). The EBL is a diffuse radiation field that pervades the universe and can interact with gamma rays, leading to gamma-ray attenuation and absorption. Jets and blazars, on the other hand, are astrophysical sources that release highly energetic particles along their axes. They are known to emit gamma rays up to tens of TeV, and their emission properties can be influenced by the EBL. Our main motivation is to understand the interplay between these two astrophysical phenomena.We employ a multi-wavelength observational approach to study the spectral and temporal behavior of jets and blazars across different energy bands. Additionally, we carry out theoretical modeling to interpret our observations and extract physical information about the sources. Our results suggest that the EBL has a significant impact on the gamma-ray emission from blazars, which can be used to infer the EBL density. We also find evidence for spectral variability and flaring activity in several sources, which can provide insights into the acceleration and emission mechanisms of high-energy particles in jets and blazars. Finally, we discuss the implications of our findings for future surveys with GLAST and other high-energy observatories.

Our work presents a novel string-derived Z' model with R-parity violation and stable proton as well as light neutrinos. The motivation for this research lies in the exploration of beyond the Standard Model scenarios and the resolution of certain drawbacks faced by existing models. We begin by constructing a new model using string theory techniques, incorporating a new symmetry U(1)B-L and a scalar field responsible for R-parity violation.Our analysis reveals several significant results. The new symmetry U(1)B-L allows for conservation of baryon number and lepton number in reactions, thus ensuring the stability of protons. The introduction of the scalar field responsible for R-parity violation leads to the production of light neutrinos, a long-standing challenge in many models.Our methodology involves the examination of the particle content, gauge symmetry, and Higgs structure of the new model. We further analyze the constraints imposed by experimental observations on the coupling parameters and mass scales of the model.Overall, our work presents a viable and consistent model with several unique features that addresses fundamental issues in the Standard Model. Our results provide fresh insights into the unification of forces and the origin of neutrino masses, compelling areas of research in theoretical physics and cosmology.

In this study, we aimed to simulate heme using the Density Functional Theory plus Hubbard U correction (DFT+U) and investigate the accuracy of spin-state energetics. Heme is an essential protein in many biological processes, including oxygen transport and electron transfer. The accurate determination of its spin-state energetics is crucial for understanding its functional mechanism. However, the spin-state energetics of heme are a challenging problem because of the strong electron correlation effects. In this study, we first validated the DFT+U approach by comparing our results with experimental data. We then compared our calculations with those from the DFT approach, which neglects electron correlation effects, and found that the DFT+U approach consistently gave a lower energy for the high-spin state than the DFT approach. Furthermore, we demonstrated that the inclusion of U significantly improves the accuracy of the energy predictions by taking into account the electron correlation effects. These findings reveal the importance of including electron correlation effects in simulating spin-state energetics of heme, and the DFT+U approach provides a reliable method for such simulations. This work paves the way for more accurate simulations of heme and other systems with strong electron correlation effects, and thus contributes to the advancement of computational chemistry and materials science.

We present an integral field spectroscopic study of the extended emission-line region (EELR) of the high redshift quasar 4C 37.43. Motivated by the need to gain a deeper understanding of the environment surrounding quasars at earlier cosmic times, we use observations obtained with the Multi Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE) instrument mounted on the Very Large Telescope (VLT). Our key idea is to study the EELR, a region of ionized gas located far beyond the host galaxy, through a spatially resolved analysis of its kinematic properties, line ratios and ionization mechanisms. Our methodology consists of a combination of techniques such as spectral extraction, flux calibration, continuum subtraction, and emission-line fitting, which together allow us to obtain a detailed spatially resolved picture of the EELR. Our results indicate the presence of complex kinematic patterns, including the detection of outflowing gas in close proximity to the quasar, as well as strong evidence for an ionization gradient within the EELR. Our findings suggest a possible connection between the quasar and the EELR, indicating that the EELR may be ionized by the quasar itself or by a collimated outflowing wind from the central engine.

In this work, we investigate the use of Super-Poissonian Shot Noise (SPSN) as a measure of dephasing in closed quantum dots. The motivation for this research is to better understand the dephasing process in quantum dots, which is a crucial factor in determining their functionality and feasibility for technological applications.To this end, we performed a series of high-precision measurements of SPSN in a closed quantum dot system. Our results revealed that the SPSN signals in our system were strongly influenced by external noise sources, such as fluctuations in the environment and charge noise from nearby electronic devices. Despite these challenges, we were able to extract reliable SPSN measures, which allowed us to accurately estimate the dephasing time of our system. Our findings have important implications for the development of future quantum dot-based technologies, as they provide insights into the fundamental physics of quantum dot dephasing. The problem that our work attempts to solve is the development of reliable methods for characterizing dephasing in closed quantum dots, which is a key step towards the realization of robust quantum computing and other quantum-based technologies.

In this paper, we propose a novel tool for seismologists, the Cumulative Spectral Power (CSP). Our motivation for this research stems from the inadequacy of current methods in identifying small earthquakes buried within noise and larger earthquakes. The CSP is designed to assist in readjusting a dataset in such a way that it highlights the frequency content of small earthquakes and at the same time dampens the frequency content of larger earthquakes and noise. The key idea of this new tool is that it enforces the idea that small earthquakes within a given frequency band can reveal substantive information about the subsurface structure of the Earth. The CSP is created using a moving time window and a cumulative distribution function of the spectral power. Our primary methodology for testing the effectiveness of the CSP is through numerical simulations and field data analysis, which shows that CSP can significantly improve the detection of small earthquakes. We anticipate that this new tool will be critical in unraveling the Earth's subsurface structures and aid seismologists in image reconstruction and monitoring earthquake activity.

We present a novel approach in addressing the long-standing problem of calculating scattering amplitudes in strongly coupled (N=4) super Yang-Mills theory via semiclassical strings in anti-de Sitter (AdS) spacetime. Our study aims to provide a deeper understanding of the holographic correspondence between the strongly coupled gauge theory and the weakly coupled gravitational theory in AdS/CFT, which is of utmost importance in developing a complete theory of quantum gravity.Using the formalism of the twistor-string theory, we derive a twistor-space representation of the semiclassical string partition function in AdS. By computing the semiclassical three-point amplitude of scattering states in AdS, we demonstrate the consistency of our approach with the standard CFT correlator calculation in the planar limit. Furthermore, we accurately verify the correspondence of semiclassical strings with the all-loop amplitudes in the gauge theory.Our work significantly advances the understanding of the AdS/CFT correspondence and provides new insights into the nature of string theory and quantum gravity. The methodology, based on the twistor-string formalism, opens new avenues for exploring string theory and gauge theory and lays the groundwork for future research in these fields.

In this study, we investigate the radion phenomenology in realistic warped space models motivated by the theoretical and experimental challenges to explain the hierarchy of the fermion masses and the existing tension between the precision electroweak measurements and direct searches for new physics. We consider a five-dimensional Randall-Sundrum model with a bulk scalar and fermion fields and a brane-localized Higgs field. We show that the radion and KK-graviton excitations can have important implications for the collider and cosmological observables. In particular, we analyze the effective couplings and decay modes of the radion in the diphoton and diphoton+dijet channels at the Large Hadron Collider and explore the parameter space that can lead to a detectable signal. We find that the radion can have a significant contribution to the diphoton excess observed by ATLAS and CMS experiments around a mass of 750 GeV. Furthermore, we investigate the radion interactions with the cosmic microwave background and dark matter and show that the radion can have effects on the early universe and on the present-day abundance of dark matter. Our study provides insights into the rich phenomenology of warped extra dimensions and highlights the importance of future experimental and observational probes.Keywords: radion phenomenology, warped space models, Randall-Sundrum model, collider physics, dark matter.

The present work offers a detailed optical and X-ray analysis of the cooling flow cluster Z3146, named ARCRAIDER I. Our analysis confirms a strong cD galaxy at the center of the cluster, surrounded by a cooling flow of gas. The spatially resolved spectral analysis shows that the intra-cluster medium (ICM) is hot in the cluster's center and cools down radially, reaching temperatures of around 2 keV at the edge. We also found a clear anti-correlation between temperature and metallicity, where the central ICM is enriched in heavy elements, while the outskirts hold a higher concentration of lighter elements.This research provides essential information about the complex processes involved in the cooling flow mechanism, which is vital for further understanding the evolution of galaxy clusters. Such analyses are necessary to comprehend the cooling flows' fundamental properties and their connection to the galaxy cluster properties. Additionally, studying the metallicity distribution in the ICM not only provides crucial information about the elemental abundances but also helps trace the history of star formation in the cluster.The results obtained in this work serve as a significant contribution to the ever-growing body of knowledge on cluster evolution and can serve as a launching point for further research in this field. The analysis presented here attempts to solve the problem of shedding light on the nature of cooling flows and metallicity distribution, which has been a long-standing source of debate and research in the cosmological community.

In this study, we present the observation of electron-hole puddles (EHPs) in graphene using a scanning single electron transistor (SSET). Graphene has aroused great interest in the scientific community due to its unique electronic and physical properties. However, the understanding of its electronic behavior is still incomplete, and the investigation of EHPs is of utmost importance to elucidate the doping and scattering mechanisms in graphene. The problem we aim to solve is to provide a reliable and accurate method for imaging the local electronic properties of graphene, especially in the vicinity of defects or dopants. The key idea of our research is to employ a sensitive and high-resolution SSET as a probe to map the electrostatic potential in graphene and detect the local density of states (LDOS). The methodology consists of fabricating the SSET, depositing the graphene sample on a Si/SiO2 substrate, and scanning the SSET tip over the sample surface. Our results demonstrate the existence of EHPs in graphene and reveal their spatial distribution and size. Moreover, we show that the SSET can image EHPs with sub-10 nm resolution and quantitatively measure their LDOS. Our study sheds light on the fundamental electronic properties of graphene and paves the way for further exploring its applications in nanoelectronics and spintronics.

We present a study of the fundamental parameters of helium (He)-weak and He-strong stars. Our aim is to characterize the physical properties of these stars, which are known to have a strong impact on the understanding of stellar evolution. The methodology followed is based on spectral analysis, which allows us to derive the effective temperature, surface gravity, and chemical composition of the stars. Our sample comprises a total of 24 He-weak and 17 He-strong stars, which were analyzed using high-resolution spectroscopy data obtained with the VLT-UVES instrument. The results obtained show that He-weak stars have lower effective temperatures and surface gravities than normal stars, while He-strong stars have higher effective temperatures and surface gravities. We also find that He-strong stars exhibit enhanced metallicity, which suggests that their formation might be related to a specific chemical enrichment process. These findings are of great significance since they provide new insights into the physical properties of He-weak and He-strong stars, which may be useful to improve our understanding of the evolution of massive stars and the origin of chemical elements in the Universe.

In this work, we investigate the phenomenon of Multiple Parton Scattering (MPS) in nuclei, specifically focusing on quark-quark scattering. The problem we aim to solve is to obtain a better understanding of the scattering process of quarks in a nuclear environment. While the concept of MPS has been extensively studied, the specific details of the quark-quark scattering process in atomic nuclei remain unclear.To tackle this problem, we employ a theoretical approach that utilizes the Color Glass Condensate (CGC) effective field theory. We calculate the MPS probability of a nucleon in a nucleus to suffer two or more scattering events with a second parton. We also investigate the impact parameter dependence of our model.Our results show that the MPS probability increases with the atomic number of the nucleus and the energy of the scattering event. Additionally, the impact parameter dependence of the MPS probability shows that the probability is higher for peripheral collisions. We further demonstrate that the introduction of a quark-quark scattering mechanism effectively damps the previously found enhancement of the n-parton distribution for small parton separations.In summary, our work provides insights into the quark-quark scattering process in nuclei by investigating the MPS phenomenon. We employ a theoretical framework that allows us to make quantitative predictions, with our results showing the atomic number and collision energy dependence of the MPS probability. Our findings have the potential to impact the understanding of particle physics and refine existing models in the field.

In this work, we investigate the signatures of heavy Z-prime particles in an Extra U(1) Superstring Inspired Model (EUSIM). The EUSIM is a type of supersymmetric theory that incorporates an additional U(1) gauge symmetry beyond the Standard Model electroweak and strong interactions. The presence of this extra symmetry allows for the existence of heavy Z-prime particles, which could have significant implications for particle physics experiments and cosmology.We use the Renormalization Group Equation (RGE) analysis to study the behavior of the EUSIM with and without the inclusion of heavy Z-prime particles. We perform numerical calculations to analyze the running of the couplings and masses of the particle spectrum, including the Z-prime. We also investigate the RGE flow of the quartic coupling that governs the spontaneous symmetry breaking of the EUSIM.The motivation for this research is twofold. First, the EUSIM is a well-motivated theoretical framework that is consistent with the principles of string theory and could shed light on the physics of our universe. Second, the existence of heavy Z-prime particles could potentially be discovered in current or future particle accelerator experiments, and therefore it is crucial to understand their impact on the EUSIM.The problem that this work attempts to solve is to identify the signatures of heavy Z-prime particles in the EUSIM and to quantify their effects on the running of the couplings and masses of the particle spectrum. Our findings may have important implications for future experimental searches for new physics beyond the Standard Model.

In this work, we investigate the relationship between dimer models, free fermions, and super quantum mechanics. Dimer models are a type of statistical mechanics model that describe the formation of dimers on a lattice, while free fermions are particles that obey Fermi-Dirac statistics and can move freely in a lattice. Super quantum mechanics, on the other hand, is a generalization of quantum mechanics that incorporates supersymmetry. We aim to understand how these three concepts are related and use this understanding to gain insights into the behavior of physical systems.To achieve this, we begin by introducing the mathematical framework for dimer models, free fermions, and super quantum mechanics. We then explore how these frameworks interact, focusing on the mathematics that underline their relationship. Our key idea is that certain dimer models have a hidden supersymmetry that emerges when they are described using free fermions. We formalize this relationship using mathematical tools, including complex analysis and representation theory.Our results show that understanding the relationship between dimer models, free fermions, and super quantum mechanics provides a new perspective on the behavior of physical systems. We demonstrate this by using our insights to address several open problems in statistical mechanics and condensed matter physics. Specifically, we use our understanding of supersymmetry in dimer models to predict the existence of certain phase transitions in materials science. We conclude with a discussion of the broader implications of our work, including its potential applications in fields such as quantum computing and high-energy physics.

In this study, we present the design of parallel kinematic machine tools using kinetostatic performance criteria. Our aim is to improve the performance and accuracy of these machines, which are widely used in manufacturing and CNC machining operations. We adopt a fully analytical methodology, which enables us to optimize the design parameters for maximum performance.Our research is motivated by the need to improve the efficiency of parallel kinematic machines for industrial applications. These machines offer superior performance compared to conventional serial kinematic machines, but their design is more complex due to the presence of redundancies. Our approach focuses on identifying the optimal arrangements of these redundancies, while ensuring that the machines meet the kinetostatic performance criteria.Our results demonstrate that the proposed methodology is effective in designing high-performance parallel kinematic machines. We successfully identified the optimal kinematic arrangement for different types of machines, including 3RPU, 3RPR, and 3RRR. Moreover, we validated our designs using simulations and experiments, which showed that the machines achieve high accuracy and repeatability. Overall, our research contributes to the development of more advanced and efficient parallel kinematic machines for manufacturing and CNC machining applications.

In this work titled 'Lyman Break Galaxies at z 5: Rest-frame UV Spectra II,' we present an analysis of 35 Lyman Break Galaxies (LBGs) at redshift z 5 using high-resolution spectroscopy obtained with the Keck telescope. The problem our work attempts to solve is the characterization of the physical properties and evolution of early galaxy populations during the cosmic reionization epoch, which is a critical period in the evolution of the Universe.The motivation for our research is to understand the emergence and evolution of galaxies and their contribution to the reionization of the Universe. Our work addresses this by studying the ionizing properties and dust content of high-redshift galaxies. We use data from the Keck telescope and extract the rest-frame UV spectra of the LBGs. We then measure the equivalent widths of spectral features, such as Lyman-alpha and SiIV lines.Our key findings suggest that LBGs at z 5 have dust attenuation levels similar to local star-forming galaxies. Furthermore, we find evidence for the presence of significant outflows in the young galaxies, implying that they could be potential sources of ionizing radiation and metal enrichment in the early Universe. Our methodology involves a combination of spectral analysis and comparison with local galaxy templates.Overall, our work sheds light on the physical properties and evolution of early galaxy populations, contributing to our understanding of the Universe's history and the crucial role of galaxies in driving cosmic reionization.

In this work, we investigate the stringy E-functions of hypersurfaces and of Brieskorn singularities. Our aim is to provide a geometric interpretation and proof of the additivity theorem for the stringy E-function of a complete intersection. The key idea is to use toric geometry and the theory of Ehrhart polynomials to compute the stringy E-function of a hypersurface. We extend this computation to Brieskorn singularities using the theory of equivariant Ehrhart polynomials.We obtain explicit formulas for the stringy E-functions of certain types of hypersurfaces and Brieskorn singularities. In particular, we obtain the complete stringy E-function of the Brieskorn-Pham singularities. Our results have applications in mirror symmetry, degeneration techniques, and tropical geometry.The problem we attempt to solve is the one of characterizing the spectrum of the stringy E-function of a hypersurface. Our methodology is a combination of geometric and combinatorial techniques. We use toric geometry and the theory of Ehrhart polynomials in a novel way to obtain a new proof of the additivity theorem. The contribution of this work is a better understanding of the relationship between the geometry of a hypersurface or Brieskorn singularity and its stringy E-function.

In this work, we present the absolute calibration and characterization of the Multiband Imaging Photometer for Spitzer (MIPS). The purpose is to establish an accurate calibration of MIPS to provide reliable measurements of the infrared sky. We focus on the stellar calibrator sample and the 24 micron calibration. The sample is composed of 50 stars carefully selected to provide a wide range of spectral types and brightnesses for a comprehensive analysis. The calibration includes the investigation of the same photometric measurement on different stars, eliminating instrumental and source-specific effects in the data.Our methodology consists of observing the calibrator sample with the MIPS instrument in two modes, scanning and staring. We analyze the data to obtain the calibration constants and correction factors that are applied to all MIPS sources. We compare the results with previous calibrations, indicating where there are discrepancies or uncertainties.Our results present a better characterization of the instrument and more reliable data products. We obtained a calibration that is consistent with previous ones, but with reduced uncertainties and additional factors. The methodology used provides a solid basis for further calibration of MIPS and other infrared instrumentation.

In The Araucaria Project, we conducted a wide-field imaging survey of the WLM galaxy in the Local Group and used the luminosity variation of Cepheid variables to measure its distance accurately. Cepheids are pulsating stars whose periods of brightness variations are directly related to their intrinsic brightnesses. Therefore, by measuring their periods on high-quality images obtained over several years, we can calculate their distances from the Earth accurately. Our survey covered a 25-square-degree field around WLM with the Warsaw Telescope at Las Campanas Observatory to identify hundreds of Cepheid variables. The photometry of these variables is based on the high-quality images taken over six years with the MOSAIC II camera on the CTIO Blanco Telescope in the same field. Our analysis, which includes the period-luminosity relation calibration, provides the distance modulus of the WLM galaxy at 24.60 ± 0.05 mag. This result is consistent with the previous estimates of the WLM distance but has a dramatically reduced uncertainty. The Hubble constant value inferred from our distance modulus is also in a good agreement with other measurements from different sources. By resolving the WLM distance issue, we contribute to the precision cosmology experiments that seek accurate determination of our Universe's fundamental parameters.

In this work, we investigate the possibility of obtaining an almost supersymmetric Standard Model from intersecting D6-branes on the Z_6' orientifold. We focus on the compactification of type IIA string theory on a toroidal background with orientifold planes. We consider a six-dimensional orbifold obtained by dividing a six-dimensional torus by a Z_6' orientation, which leads to orientifold planes and D6-branes at fixed points. We study the low-energy effective theory of the D6-branes and analyze the spectrum of chiral matter under the Standard Model gauge group. We find that the resulting spectrum contains all the particles of the Standard Model, except for the right-handed neutrinos, and that the Yukawa couplings are generated by instanton effects.Our work aims to address the problem of obtaining a realistic model of particle physics from string theory. The success of the Standard Model of particle physics in explaining the experimental data leaves little room for new physics beyond the Standard Model at low energies. String theory provides a consistent framework for quantum gravity that unifies all fundamental forces, but constructing a realistic model of particle physics from string theory is a challenging task.Our approach involves the use of intersecting D6-branes and the Z_6' orientifold, which is a particularly interesting model due to its rich phenomenology. Intersecting branes provide a geometric realization of the chiral matter spectrum, while the orientifold projection allows for the cancellation of tadpoles and the breaking of supersymmetry. Our methodology involves a detailed analysis of the low-energy effective theory of the D6-branes and the computation of instanton-generated Yukawa couplings. Our results show that a realistic model of the Standard Model can be obtained from string theory using the methods of intersecting branes and orientifolds.

In our work entitled 'Detection of GRB 060927 at z = 5.47: Implications for the Use of Gamma-Ray Bursts as Probes of the End of the Dark Ages,' we aimed to study the characteristics of gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) and their potential as probes for understanding the end of the dark ages. The problem we attempted to solve was to determine if GRBs could provide insight into the formation of the first stars and galaxies, which occurred about 13 billion years ago, or if they could only illuminate the later universe at redshifts of about 5.Our key idea was to study GRB 060927 in detail since it occurred at an unprecedented redshift of 5.47. We obtained data from several telescopes and analyzed it using spectroscopy, photometry, and modeling techniques. Our results showed that GRB 060927 was an exceptionally bright and energetic burst, lasting for 10 seconds and releasing an enormous amount of energy. We also found that its host galaxy was a young dwarf galaxy, suggesting that GRBs may have contributed to the reionization of the universe in its early stages.Overall, our study highlights the potential of GRBs as probes of the early universe. Our methodology, using a combination of observational data and modeling, provides a promising approach for further investigations into the formation of the first galaxies and evolution of the universe.

In this paper, we present the results of the study of molecular gas in the nucleus of NGC4569, a galaxy presenting a strong bar feature. This research was conducted as part of the Molecular gas in NUclei of GAlaxies (NUGA) VII project. The motivation for this work stems from the need to understand the role of gas inflow in the formation and evolution of galactic nuclei. Previous studies have suggested that gas is transported towards the nuclear region through spiral arms and bars and plays a crucial role in triggering starburst activity.Our aim was to investigate the distribution and kinematics of molecular gas in the nucleus of NGC4569. Through observations with the IRAM-30m telescope, we obtained maps of the CO(1–0) and CO(2–1) emission lines. We observed a strong concentration of molecular gas at the center of the galaxy, coincident with the nucleus. We also observed a clear velocity gradient along the major axis of the galaxy, consistent with gas inflow towards the nucleus.Our findings provide further evidence for the crucial role of bar-driven gas inflows towards the nucleus of galaxies. Our work adds to the understanding of the mechanisms responsible for the formation and evolution of galactic nuclei, with implications for our understanding of the evolution of galaxies as a whole.

In this work, we present the first Hubble Space Telescope (HST) Fine Guidance Sensor (FGS) parallax measurements for AM CVn stars. We obtained astrometric data over five consecutive epochs with HST's FGS and used a maximum likelihood estimator to obtain parallax and proper motion measurements. Our study included the two known double-degenerate pulsating systems, HP Librae and V396 Herculis, and one non-pulsating AM CVn star, SDSS J1240-01. Our results show precise parallaxes of 3.91 ± 0.10 mas, 4.25 ± 0.09 mas, and 7.18 ± 0.60 mas, respectively, providing the first direct distance estimates to these systems.From these parallax measurements, we calculated the absolute magnitudes and inferred the masses of the components in the systems. Combining these with radial velocity observations, we derived the inclination angles and masses more accurately, enabling us to place the systems on the mass-transfer tracks. Our study shows that HP Lib and V396 Her have a high mass ratio and are close to the minimum period expected for AM CVn systems. Furthermore, SDSS J1240-01 has a mass ratio close to unity, implying that it is an intermediate polar candidate. We also discuss the implications of our results on the theoretical models of AM CVn systems and the production of gravitational waves. Our study provides an important step towards a more complete understanding of the AM CVn population and their astrophysical consequences.

We present a comprehensive study of the electrical and optical properties of ferromagnetic Cobalt doped Zinc Oxide (ZnO) nanoparticles, exhibiting a metal-insulator transition (MIT). We investigate the effect of Cobalt doping on the electronic structure and magnetic properties of ZnO nanoparticles. We synthesized nanoparticles using a chemical co-precipitation technique and characterized their structural, magnetic, electrical, and optical properties using various techniques. Our electrical transport measurements show a transition from metallic to insulating behavior at a critical temperature. Furthermore, optical measurements indicate that the material's optical properties change as we approach the MIT temperature, revealing a critical behavior that is consistent with a metal-insulator phase transition. Importantly, our results support the observation that the magnetic behavior of the nanoparticles becomes ferromagnetic and persists at high temperatures near the MIT. Finally, our work provides a fundamental understanding of the origin of the MIT in Cobalt doped ZnO nanoparticles, which has significant implications for the development of novel materials with promising spintronics and optoelectronics applications.

In this study, we aim to unveil the morphologies of luminous compact galaxies (LCGs) by analyzing data from the Hubble Space Telescope/Advanced Camera for Surveys (HST/ACS) GOODS survey. The main motivation for this research stems from the lack of understanding of the physical processes that lead to the formation and evolution of these galaxies.Our analysis reveals that LCGs exhibit a wide range of morphological features, including compactness, asymmetry, and clumpy structures, making them distinct from typical disk or elliptical galaxies. Moreover, we found that the majority of LCGs have undergone recent merger events, which could explain the observed features.The study also highlights the importance of high-resolution imaging in understanding the nature of LCGs, as traditional imaging techniques fail to resolve their intricate morphologies. Our findings provide crucial insights into the evolution of LCGs and open up new avenues for further investigation.Overall, this research attempts to solve the problem of uncovering the mechanisms behind the formation and evolution of LCGs. Our results provide a foundation for future studies that aim to explore the physical processes and environmental factors that shape these unique galaxies.

In this research, we present an Augmented Sparse Reconstruction (ASR) algorithm for protein signaling network reconstruction. The reconstruction of protein signaling networks is a challenging task due to the complex and dynamic nature of cellular signaling. Existing methods have limited scalability and accuracy in large- scale signaling datasets. ASR aims to address this problem by integrating prior knowledge of signaling pathways and data-driven information from experimental observations.We evaluate ASR on simulated and real-world datasets and compare its performance against state-of-the-art methods. The results demonstrate that ASR yields higher accuracy and network sparsity while achieving faster runtime than existing methods. We also apply ASR to reconstruct human protein signaling networks, and we identify multiple novel pathway interactions and crosstalk between pathways.The motivation for this research stems from the need for an accurate and efficient method for protein signaling network reconstruction, which is crucial for understanding cellular signaling mechanisms and developing effective therapeutic strategies. The proposed ASR algorithm provides a promising approach that can contribute to the advancement of fundamental biological research and clinical applications.

Our research aimed to enhance the lifetime of wireless sensor networks (WSNs) with the collaborative beamforming and cooperative transmission (CBCT) approach. WSNs have a limited lifespan due to their battery constraints, and in many cases, replacing them is not practical. Therefore, extending the lifetime of WSN is of great importance.We proposed a novel CBCT approach that combines two techniques, collaboration among sensor nodes and beamforming. The proposed approach optimizes the energy efficiency of the network by reducing the energy consumption of each node. The CBCT approach also makes the transmission more reliable and resilient against interferences and obstacles.Our experimental simulations showed that the proposed CBCT method could improve the network's lifetime by nearly 20

In this work, we present the results of optical spectroscopy observations of a sample of Extreme High Energy Peaked BL Lac objects (EHBLs). EHBLs are a class of blazars that exhibit exceedingly high synchrotron peak frequencies, which make them particularly interesting targets for multi-wavelength studies. Our goal is to study their properties and determine their redshifts in order to understand their physical nature and the mechanisms that produce such high-energy emission. We used the 6.5m Magellan/Baade telescope located in Chile to observe 8 EHBLs, resulting in successful spectroscopic redshift measurements for 5 of them, with values ranging from z=0.07 to z=0.55. These new redshift measurements can help constrain models of EHBLs' formation and evolution. Furthermore, we confirm previous reports of the presence of broad emission lines in EHBLs, suggesting the presence of an accretion disk. Our study highlights the importance of multi-wavelength observations to better understand the nature of EHBLs, and the potential for upcoming facilities like the Cherenkov Telescope Array to provide important new insights in this field.

In this work, we investigate the subpulse modulation (SPM) properties of pulsars at 92 cm and the frequency dependence of SPM. The SPM phenomenon refers to the time-varying features present in the pulsar emission pattern, which are thought to arise due to instabilities in the magnetosphere surrounding the pulsar. In particular, we focus on the frequency dependence of SPM, which is currently not well-understood.Our work attempts to shed light on this problem by utilizing new data obtained from the giant Metrewave Radio Telescope (GMRT) at a frequency of 327 MHz. We analyze the data using a number of statistical techniques to quantify the SPM properties of 11 pulsars. Our analysis reveals that the properties of SPM are not only pulsar-specific but also show strong dependence on observing frequency. We find evidence of a decrease in SPM period with increasing observing frequency for at least one pulsar.Our results have important implications for understanding the underlying physics behind SPM. Furthermore, they demonstrate the need for further observations at different frequencies to fully grasp the frequency dependence of SPM. Such investigations could provide vital clues to the physical mechanisms behind radio emission from pulsars, which remain poorly understood.

In this work, our aim was to investigate the potential of using antiproliferative MCR peptides to block the physical interaction of insulin with the retinoblastoma protein (RB) in human lung cancer cells. The issue we sought to address was the observation that insulin appears to play a role in modulating the activity of RB, which is a critical protein involved in the regulation of cell cycle progression. With this in mind, we hypothesized that disrupting the interaction between insulin and RB may have therapeutic potential for the treatment of lung cancer.To test our hypothesis, we utilized a combination of cell-based assays and molecular modeling. Our results demonstrate that the MCR peptides effectively block the interaction between insulin and RB in lung cancer cells, leading to a reduction in cell proliferation and an increase in cell death. Importantly, we also found that the peptides did not have any significant effect on normal lung cells.Overall, our study provides evidence that blocking the physical interaction between insulin and RB using MCR peptides may be a promising strategy for the treatment of lung cancer. Further research is needed to fully understand the mechanism of action of these peptides and to optimize their efficacy and safety in vivo.

In this paper, we present a detailed study of the gas and star formation mechanisms in a highly magnified Lyman Break Galaxy (LBG) at z=3.07. Our goal is to explore the physical properties of the galaxy and to understand the underlying processes behind its formation. To achieve this, we analyzed the magnified images of the galaxy, obtained through gravitational lensing, using a suite of observational techniques.Our analysis revealed that the LBG has a massive, dusty disk-like structure, which is consistent with a rotating gas disk. We also found that the galaxy has an extremely high star formation rate, which is fueled by a high gas mass and a favorable gas surface density. Our results support the hypothesis that galaxy mergers and gas accretion play a significant role in the formation of high-redshift galaxies.The methodology employed in this work includes a combination of spectroscopic and photometric observations, along with gravitational lens modeling. Our results shed light on the physical processes behind star formation and gas dynamics, in high redshift galaxies, and provide valuable insights into our understanding of the early Universe.Overall, this study contributes to the ongoing efforts to better understand the formation and evolution of high redshift galaxies. It also highlights the importance of combining observational data with sophisticated modeling techniques to obtain a better understanding of complex astrophysical phenomena.

We present a study on the kinematic evolution of strong MgII absorbers and their relationship with galaxy evolution. Strong MgII absorbers are a class of quasar absorption lines that arise from dense gas clouds, and are considered a useful probe of the interstellar medium (ISM) and circumgalactic medium (CGM) of galaxies at moderate redshifts. Our work aims to address the question of whether strong MgII absorbers arise from outflows or inflows.We perform a detailed analysis of the kinematic properties of 248 strong MgII absorbers at z0.5 - 1.5 using high-resolution spectroscopic data from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey. We find that strong MgII absorbers are not randomly distributed in velocity space, but instead exhibit ordered kinematic patterns that vary with redshift. Our results suggest that at higher redshifts, strong MgII absorbers tend to arise from outflows, while at lower redshifts they preferentially trace inflows toward galaxies. We investigate possible correlations between MgII absorption and galaxy properties, such as star formation rate, metallicity, and environment.Our work provides new insights into the kinematic properties and evolution of the CGM and ISM of galaxies over cosmic time. We employ various statistical methods, including clustering and principal component analysis, to extract the key kinematic features of MgII absorbers. Our findings support the idea that MgII absorbers arise from a diverse range of physical processes, including galactic winds, accretion, and merger events. Our study lays the foundation for future investigations of the link between MgII absorption and galaxy evolution, which will require larger and more comprehensive datasets.

In this paper, we present a study on Flavour-Dependent Type II Leptogenesis. The main idea behind our work is that the observed baryon asymmetry in the Universe can be explained if the lepton number violation occurs through the decay of heavy Majorana neutrinos. In this model, the decay of these neutrinos generates a lepton asymmetry which is partially converted into a baryon asymmetry through sphaleron processes. The aim of this work is to investigate how the flavour structure of the heavy Majorana neutrino Yukawa couplings affects the generated lepton asymmetry.We develop a novel formalism that allows us to analytically calculate the lepton asymmetry in a generic flavour basis. We show that the resulting baryon asymmetry can be significantly enhanced or suppressed, depending on the Yukawa couplings' flavour structure. Additionally, we perform numerical studies of a specific model based on the SO(10) grand unified theory. In this model, the Yukawa couplings come from a single 10-plet Higgs field. We find that a flavour-dependent type II leptogenesis can explain the observed baryon asymmetry in this model.Our motivation for this work comes from the fact that the observed baryon asymmetry in the Universe is one of the most significant puzzles of modern cosmology. Therefore, understanding the origin of this asymmetry is of great importance. Our results provide new insight into the role of neutrino Yukawa couplings in the generation of the baryon asymmetry and open up new avenues for future research in this field.

We present a comparison between anomalous 6-cm formaldehyde (H_2CO) absorption and CO(1-0) emission in the L1204/S140 region. The motivation behind this study is to investigate the relationship between molecular gas and dense cloud cores in this region, which is undergoing active star formation. Key methodology involved analyzing archival radio data from the Green Bank Telescope (GBT) and the Five College Radio Astronomy Observatory (FCRAO). We identified six H_2CO absorption features and found that the H_2CO absorption profiles and CO(1-0) emission have different shapes, peak velocities, and velocity dispersions. Our results suggest that the anomalous H_2CO absorption may be tracing different physical conditions compared to CO(1-0) emission, such as smaller dense cores associated with embedded protostars. This is supported by previous observations of compact H_2CO emission in other star-forming regions. Our findings highlight the importance of multi-wavelength studies to better understand the complex interplay between gas dynamics and star formation. Further studies are necessary to confirm these results and investigate the properties of the dense cores associated with the anomalous H_2CO absorption.

In this work, we explore the connection between information, information processing and gravity. Our investigation is motivated by a fundamental question: Can information be related to gravity? To address this question, we utilize a theoretical framework that allows us to study the perturbative quantum effects of gravity in the presence of information fields. Specifically, we model the interaction of gravitons with quantum bits (qubits) and show how the interaction leads to non-local entanglement between qubits.Our key finding is that the presence of information has a profound impact on the behavior of gravitons and, consequently, on the dynamics of gravity. We demonstrate that information-carrying qubits modify the gravitational potential, causing deviations from classical Newtonian gravity. Moreover, we show that it is possible to manipulate the gravitational force using carefully designed information processing schemes.Our work shines light on the deep connection between information, information processing and the nature of gravity. It opens up new avenues for exploring the role of information in physical theory and for developing new technologies that leverage the quantum properties of information to control and manipulate the gravitational force.

In our work titled 'Stellar Evolution in NGC 6791: Mass Loss on the Red Giant Branch and the Formation of Low Mass White Dwarfs,' we investigated the mass loss of stars on the red giant branch (RGB) and the formation of low mass white dwarfs (WDs) in NGC 6791. This open cluster is ideal for studying stellar evolution due to its advanced age of8 Gyr and high metallicity.We characterized the mass loss rates of 18 RGB stars in NGC 6791 through spectral analysis of molecular bands. We found that the mass loss rates were significantly higher than those predicted by theoretical models. Additionally, we identified eight low mass white dwarfs (WDs) in the cluster. Based on our analysis, we suggest that these WDs were formed through direct accretion of RGB winds onto low mass companion stars. This contradicts previous studies that suggested mass transfer in binary systems as the primary mechanism for the formation of low mass WDs.Our findings have important implications for our understanding of stellar evolution and the formation of WDs in open clusters. Our methodology, which combined spectroscopic analysis and theoretical modeling, can be applied to other clusters to improve our understanding of mass loss and WD formation mechanisms.

In this research, we investigate the predictability of the solar cycle using mean-field models, a popular tool in the field of solar physics. Our motivation for this investigation is to improve our understanding of the solar cycle and to make accurate predictions of its activity. To achieve this goal, we first propose a new approach that combines mean-field models with the Bayesian framework. This method allows the incorporation of new observations over time and provides us with a constantly updated estimate of the solar activity levels. We then apply this approach to the observed solar cycle data and compare our predictions with the actual observations. Our analysis shows that our new method outperforms the traditional mean-field models and provides more accurate predictions of the solar cycle. Furthermore, we use our approach to make predictions for the next solar cycle, which is expected to peak around 2025. Our results suggest that the activity levels during the next solar cycle will be similar to the current cycle, with a peak in activity around 2025. Our findings have important implications for predicting the effects of solar activity on Earth's climate and for forecasting space weather events.

In our work, we explore the top quark production in association with nonstandard, strongly interacting spin one particles at the Tevatron and LHC. The motivation for our research stems from the need to explain the unusual events observed in the experiments at these facilities. These events suggest the presence of new physics beyond the standard model.The problem we aim to solve is to identify the possible scenarios of new physics responsible for these unusual events. We focus on the top quark production because of its high sensitivity to new physics. We study the top quark pair production in association with a spin one particle in the effective field theory framework. We consider the scenarios where the spin one particle is a vector boson that couples with the top quark through the axial or the vector current.Our methodology involves a detailed analysis of the theoretical and experimental constraints on the model parameters. We calculate the cross-sections and the differential distributions for the top quark pair production in association with the spin one particle. We compare the theoretical predictions with the experimental data from the Tevatron and LHC experiments.Our results show that the top quark production in association with a spin one particle can provide a good explanation for the unusual events observed at the Tevatron and LHC experiments. We propose some specific tests to distinguish our scenarios from the other possible new physics scenarios. Our work provides a crucial step towards a better understanding of the physics beyond the standard model.

In this study, we investigate the dynamic interactions between gamma-ray burst (GRB) blast waves and wind-shaped circumburst media. GRBs are the most powerful explosions in the universe that release immense amounts of energy in a short span of time. They occur when a massive star collapses or two neutron stars merge. The blast wave produced during a GRB can rapidly generate a shock wave that interacts with the surrounding circumburst medium. The complex structure and dynamics of the medium pose challenges in understanding the morphology and physical properties of the shock wave. Therefore, we aim to explore the fundamental mechanisms of shock wave propagation and evolution through a wind-shaped circumburst medium.The motivation for our research is to develop a comprehensive understanding of the underlying mechanisms governing the physical properties of the GRB blast wave. We aim to provide insights into processes such as turbulence, instabilities, and shocks that occur during the interaction of the blast wave with the surrounding medium. Our study offers a unique approach to modeling and simulating the evolution of GRB blast waves and their interaction with the circumburst medium.To achieve our objectives, we employ a numerical simulation technique that solves the equations governing the dynamics of the circumburst medium and the blast wave simultaneously. The numerical simulations are carried out using the adaptive mesh refinement technique. Our findings show that the dynamic properties of the medium play a crucial role in controlling the morphology and evolution of the blast wave. In conclusion, our research provides new insights into the physics of GRB blast waves and can lead to improved models of these explosive events in the universe.

In this work, we sought to constrain the geometry of the neutron star RX J1856.5-3754, a crucial step to understand the physics of these extreme objects. Using data from the XMM-Newton space telescope, we applied a novel spectral model that accounts for the effects of the interstellar medium to the X-ray spectrum of the neutron star. This allowed us to derive a more accurate estimate of the hydrogen column density towards the object and thus, better estimate its distance. We also used data from the Hubble Space Telescope to search for a possible optical counterpart, which would provide additional constraints on the distance and the system's geometry.Our main result is the first measurement of the distance to RX J1856.5-3754 with an accuracy of 6

In this study, we investigate the dynamic response of Ag monolayers adsorbed on Au(100) under an oscillatory change of the chemical potential using Monte Carlo simulation. We aim to understand the behavior of Ag atoms on Au(100) in terms of their mobility and stability. Monte Carlo simulation is a powerful tool for studying the dynamic behavior of atoms on surfaces. The simulation was carried out by using Metropolis Monte Carlo (MMC) algorithm, which enables us to sample the probability distribution of the system.Our results indicate that the Ag atoms on Au(100) show unique dynamic behavior in response to oscillatory change of the chemical potential. We found that the presence of Au atoms in the vicinity of Ag atoms increases their mobility, and Ag atoms exhibit a tendency to aggregate under a positive chemical potential while their dispersion is promoted under a negative chemical potential. This study provides insights into the dynamic behavior of adsorbed monolayers under oscillatory conditions, which is important in understanding the behavior of surfaces in technological applications.The problem we attempt to solve in this study is to gain a deeper understanding of the dynamic behavior of Ag monolayers on Au(100) under oscillatory change of chemical potential. This knowledge is essential in controlling the behavior of surfaces in various technological applications such as catalysis, coating, and materials science. Our study contributes to the fundamental understanding of surface phenomena and provides valuable information for the development of new technologies.

In this paper, we provide a critical review of the statistical analysis presented in 'A new experimental limit for the stability of the electron' by H.V. Klapdor-Kleingrothaus, I.V. Krivosheina, and I.V. Titkova. The authors aim to test the hypothesis that the electron, a fundamental particle in physics, is stable over long periods of time. The methodology used involves conducting an experiment to search for evidence of electron decay and performing a statistical analysis of the collected data.Our analysis highlights potential issues with the methodology used in the study, including the lack of a clear statistical model and the failure to account for multiple testing. Additionally, we note that the study's results are highly dependent on the choice of prior probability distributions, which may introduce bias. We suggest that future studies investigating the stability of the electron should address these issues to ensure the reliability of their results.Overall, this work attempts to contribute to the rigorous evaluation of experimental findings in physics research. By identifying potential pitfalls in statistical analysis, we hope to encourage researchers to carefully consider their methods and interpretations to advance our understanding of the fundamental laws of nature.

In this paper, we present the measurement of the top-quark mass using missing E_T+jets events with secondary vertex b-tagging at the CDF II particle collider. The top-quark is the heaviest known elementary particle and its mass is a fundamental parameter in the Standard Model of particle physics. Precise measurement of the top-quark mass is crucial to test the consistency of the Standard Model and to search for new physics beyond it.Our goal was to measure the top-quark mass using a novel method consisting of selecting events that have missing transverse energy (MET) and at least one jet that contains a secondary vertex identified as a b-jet. We analyzed data collected in proton-antiproton collisions at √(s) = 1.96 TeV by the CDF II detector, located at the Fermilab Tevatron accelerator.The key idea of our analysis was to construct a template of the top-quark mass distribution by fitting the MET distribution in data and comparing it to the prediction from simulation. We used a Bayesian approach to extract the top-quark mass and its uncertainty. Our method has the advantage of being less sensitive to the jet energy scale and resolution uncertainties, compared to traditional top-quark mass measurements.Our result for the top-quark mass is 172.8 ± 2.2 (stat.)± 1.5 (syst.) GeV/c^2, which is one of the most precise measurements to date. This measurement contributes to the global effort to improve the knowledge of the top-quark mass and to search for new physics phenomena.

In this work, we investigate the behaviour of a brane moving in a bulk spacetime with the cosmological constant. Specifically, we consider a single (1 + 1)-dimensional timelike brane, which undergoes Lorentzian signature change as it moves through the bulk spacetime. Lorentzian signature change in the brane worldvolume can be interpreted as a phase transition in the effective theory describing the motion of the brane. In our study, we derive the boundary conditions satisfied by the brane worldvolume and compute the Hamiltonian, which describes the dynamics of the brane. We also investigate the existence and properties of special solutions, namely, bouncing branes and static branes. Moreover, we analyze the properties of the trajectory and the phase diagram of the brane in the bulk spacetime. Our results demonstrate that the dynamics of the brane is significantly modified by the introduction of the signature change and provides a richer set of solutions beyond the conventional Dirac-Born-Infeld equations. The motivation for our work comes from the need to explore a larger class of solutions in the brane worldvolume theory that may be relevant for cosmological and high energy physics.

In this work, we present the results of our multicolor observations of the afterglow of the short/hard GRB 050724. Our motivation for this research is to better understand the physical mechanisms responsible for the prompt emission and afterglow of short/hard gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) and their associated host environments. Short/hard GRBs are brief, intense bursts of gamma-ray radiation with durations of less than two seconds. Unlike long-duration GRBs, they are not associated with supernova explosions and are believed to be produced by mergers of compact objects such as neutron stars or black holes.Our observations were carried out using the 2.2-m telescope at Calar Alto Observatory in Spain and the 8.2-m Subaru Telescope in Hawaii. We obtained multicolor photometric data over several epochs spanning a few hours to several days following the GRB. We used these data to construct the spectral energy distribution (SED) of the afterglow, which allowed us to derive its physical properties such as the electron energy distribution and the density of the surrounding medium.Our analysis showed that the afterglow of GRB 050724 had a steep spectral slope, indicating that the electron energy distribution was particularly steep. This is in contrast to what is typically observed for long-duration GRBs. Our observations also revealed a possible break in the afterglow light curve, which could be due to either a jet break or the injection of fresh energy into the blast wave. Our study provides valuable insights into the physics of short/hard GRBs and their associated host environments.

The Cornell Caltech Atacama Telescope (CCAT) is a state-of-the-art millimeter-wave telescope that aims to explore the universe's mysteries by capturing images of galaxies, stars, and interstellar gas. The instrument is located at one of the world's highest and driest observatory sites, in the Atacama Desert of Chile, presenting extraordinary possibilities for deep sky surveys. The CCAT is a collaboration between Cornell University and Caltech, which has proven effective for the development of exemplary instrumentation for astronomy. The primary goal of this research is to present the design of the telescope and its features, operational capabilities, and performance measurement techniques.The CCAT is a comprehensive observatory that uses the latest innovations and technologies to detect and study cosmic phenomena. This study aims to address the significant challenges associated with simulating telescopes. The team used advanced software to model the telescope and then used validated simulations to verify how multiple operational configurations of the CCAT would perform. In addition, the team performed sensitivity studies to investigate the optimal observing configurations.The research has resulted in a detailed analysis of the CCAT telescope's functionality and potential use of simulating telescopes. The team has shown that the CCAT will have outstanding performance in achieving the science goals outlined in this research. The CCAT is anticipated to transform the study of astronomy significantly and lead to a better understanding of the current cosmological model. The collaborative work done on the CCAT telescope by Cornell University and Caltech marks an exciting phase in astronomical research.

In this study, we investigate the growth mechanisms and structure of fullerene-like carbon-based thin films for use as superelastic materials in tribological applications. The problem at hand is the need for high-performance materials with superior wear resistance and elasticity, particularly in harsh environments. Our work seeks to address this issue by examining the growth mechanisms and structure of carbon-based thin films to identify their potential as tribological materials.Results from analysis using atomic force microscopy (AFM), Raman spectroscopy, and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) indicate that the thin films possess a fullerene-like structure consisting of carbon atoms arranged in a closed cage-like structure with a slight distortion. The films exhibit superelastic behavior with recoverable plastic strains of up to 8

We present an analysis of the outer jet X-ray and radio emission in R Aquarii from 1999.8 to 2004.0 using Chandra X-ray Observatory and Multi-Element Radio-Linked Interferometer Network (MERLIN) data. R Aquarii is a symbiotic star system consisting of a red giant and a white dwarf in a binary system. It is known for its extended bipolar jet that manifests in both X-ray and radio frequencies. Our work aims to study the temporal variability of the outer jet emission over five years and understand the interplay between different physical mechanisms responsible for the observed emission.The motivation for this research is to gain insights into the physical processes involved in the formation and evolution of the R Aquarii jet and study the effects of the interaction between the jet and ambient medium. We use spectral and imaging analyses to characterize the jet emission and investigate the effects of shocks and synchrotron radiation in the jet. The methodology adopted involves analyzing X-ray and radio light curves, spectra, images, and comparing the results with state-of-the-art models.Our study shows a complex temporal behavior of the outer jet emission that is attributed to the interaction between the jet and the surrounding medium. The spectral analysis indicates that the jet is powered by a combination of thermal and non-thermal mechanisms, and synchrotron radiation is a dominant contributor to the radio emission. Further, the imaging analysis reveals a limb-brightened outer jet morphology with evidence of shocks and precessional motion. Overall, our work provides valuable insights into the physics of the jet in R Aquarii and highlights the importance of multiwavelength studies to understand the nature of astrophysical jets.

In this study, we present the results of our analysis of the near-infrared spectra of the black hole X-ray binary, A0620-00. Black hole X-ray binaries provide an ideal environment to study the strong gravitational effects of black holes on their companion star. They also provide crucial insights into the formation and evolution of binary systems. The near-infrared region of the electromagnetic spectrum is particularly useful in these studies because it allows us to probe the innermost regions of the system, where the black hole exerts the strongest gravitational forces.Our goal was to analyze the near-infrared spectra of A0620-00 and decipher the properties of the system. Using high-resolution spectra obtained from the Gemini Near-Infrared Spectrograph (GNIRS), we were able to extract several important features of the system. We identified the presence of a hot accretion disk around the black hole, which emits intense near-infrared radiation. We also detected the signature of the companion star, a low-mass red dwarf, which is orbiting the black hole every 7.75 hours.Our findings provide important insights into the physics of black hole X-ray binaries and their evolution. Our study also highlights the usefulness of near-infrared observations in studying these systems. Further studies in this field will undoubtedly shed more light on the mysteries of black holes and their interactions with their surroundings.

In this work, we investigate the scaling relations of compressible magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) turbulence using high-resolution numerical simulations. Turbulence is a ubiquitous phenomenon in nature and plays a vital role in astrophysical systems such as the interstellar medium, accretion disks, and the solar wind. Our main objective is to elucidate the scaling properties of compressible MHD turbulence and identify the physical mechanisms that govern its dynamics.We use a pseudospectral method to solve the compressible MHD equations in a periodic box with isothermal conditions. We employ a range of magnetic field strengths and sonic Mach numbers to study the effects of varying parameters on the scaling relations. We find that the compressible modes of turbulence exhibit different scaling properties compared to incompressible turbulence. Moreover, the anisotropy of the turbulence is found to be dependent on the strength of the magnetic field.Our research provides insights into the fundamental nature of compressible MHD turbulence and its dependencies on the underlying physics. These findings can be used to improve our understanding of astrophysical phenomena and enable us to make more accurate predictions of the behavior of these complex systems.

In this study, we investigate Ly-alpha Emission-Line Galaxies (LAEs) at redshift z = 3.1 in the Extended Chandra Deep Field South (ECDFS) using deep spectroscopic observations with VIMOS on the Very Large Telescope. One of the key motivations for this research is to explore the properties of LAEs at high redshifts. LAEs are among the most numerous galaxies during the epoch of reionization, and studying them can reveal important information about the early universe. Through our analysis, we aim to understand the nature, properties, and evolution of these galaxies.We use a spectral stacking method to improve the signal-to-noise ratio of our observations and to study the average properties of a large sample of LAEs. Our results show that LAEs have strong Ly-alpha emission, consistent with previous observations. We find that the equivalent width of the Ly-alpha line in our sample is significantly higher than in previous studies, which suggests that these LAEs are highly ionized. Moreover, our analysis shows evidence of significant Ly-alpha escape fraction, which indicates that these galaxies could be important sources for reionization.In conclusion, our study provides valuable insights into the properties of LAEs at high redshifts and their potential role in reionization. Our method can be extended to larger samples in the future, opening up opportunities for a deeper understanding of the early universe.

In this study, we present new observations and analyses of the light curves and colours of the faint irregular satellites of Uranus: Sycorax, Prospero, Stephano, Setebos, and Trinculo. These moons are interesting objects to study due to their irregular orbits and suspected captured origin. However, their faintness and low surface albedo make them challenging targets for observation and analysis.The motivation for this research is to better understand the physical characteristics of these small Uranian moons and to study their formation and evolution. Our work attempts to solve the problem of the lack of comprehensive data on these objects and to provide a more detailed understanding of their rotational properties and surface heterogeneity.Our key idea is to use multi-filter observations of the moons’ brightness variability to study their rotational properties and surface compositions. We analysed our data using Fourier analysis to determine the rotational periods of each moon and used colour indices to study their surface compositions.
